title: Does smoking marijuana before writing help in the creative process? - Quora

response.answer_text: Sure, cannabis can help stimulate your creativity. So can going for a run, a sip from a nice scotch, or even a conversation with an old friend. The point being, anything can be used as a tool in the creative writing process. That being said, cannabis offers many benefits that can help with writing when used appropriately, and some shortcomings that can become a hinderance when used excessively. When writing, I enjoy concentrates and uplifting strain options as I feel that I have more control over the creative process with these choices. While I love smoking cannabis flower, I find it to be more recreational and relaxing, even if used in an energetic setting, than I do other mediums. Edibles and concentrates with uplifting terpene blends ensure that I won’t fall asleep on the couch when I’m trying to work. As a writer, cannabis helps me narrow my focus, intensifying my attention to the subject at hand and the voice of the piece. This can be incredibly useful in freelance and ghostwriting situations as you attempt to write from someone else’s perspective, tone and personality. It can also help you table topics and distractions that impede your ability to focus on your writing. We all live chaotic lives full of obligations, rewards, goals, relationships, and the unplanned, which all can make it hard to sit down and put pen to paper, especially in a creative format. Cannabis can ease you into that mode and allow you to enjoy the task at hand with minimal distractions. Most would agree that cannabis can stimulate your imagination as well. When your bran is processing cannabinoids, it often “connects the dots” in ways you might not have if you’d chosen not to smoke. “High Ideas” and the concept of “stoned” thinking have a basis in truth as cannabinoids are mind-altering and can allow you to think in new ways and of new ideas. It’s well documented that many individuals that are hailed as visionaries, especially in the technology field, have experimenting with cannabis and mind-altering substances as a way to allow them to think differently about their situation to come up with unique, breaking edge ideas. All of this should be taken with the grain of salt that cannabis is not for everyone, and the positive effects of cannabis are seen through moderation and effective titration. If you take a puff and realize cannabis isn’t for you, don’t try to consume more thinking that you “aren’t there yet” or that in larger amounts the situation might change. Similarly, if you enjoy your cannabis experience, know your limits and consume accordingly; use it purposively to enhance your efforts without consuming so much so that it hinders them. If you notice certain strains or types of cannabis that you prefer, such as edibles or concentrates, selectively purchase options for both personal enjoyment and creative use, respecting the variety of applications that the different cannabis plants can offer.  Thank you for reading! If you enjoyed or learned something from this answer, please click ‘upvote’ below.

I am a professional writer/editor and I use cannabis daily, but I had to learn several lessons to get to the point I am at today. Not all strains are created equal in terms of creativity. I’ve mentioned this other answers - I actually spent a good deal of time experimenting with different strains when I entered the legal industry in Colorado. I have a notebook where I would test different strains, write down their effects, how long it took to onset, how long the effects lasted, and if there were any side effects. Part of my process of this experimentation included attempting to write a paragraph while I was ‘under the influence.’ Here’s what I learned through my assessments: Hybrids worked best for creativity for me. Strong sativas usually made me too racy to focus, while heavy indicas distracted me and made me foggy. For me - any derivative of OG Kush is a creativity killer - I couldn’t write to save my soul after smoking this strain, lol.Limonene is a God-send for creativity. If it smells of lemony, citrus goodness - I am all in. I can bang out 1000 words in no time with a little boost from this essential oil.Anything with a high CBG content is uplifting and energizing.Also, although it’s wildly debated whether Hemingway actually said it or not - but “Write drunk, edit sober” is good word of caution. If you write under the influence of anything - for the love of all that’s holy (speaking from experience as an editor) - USE YOUR GRAMMAR CHECKER!!! Or at least read it back to yourself later, have someone else read it, or just have Word read it back to you, so you can “hear” it from another voice. Chances are “sober you” will hear it differently than “stoned you” did while you were writing it. :)

I think it depends. I published a story that came from drinking in an old barroom in San Francisco. It is a pretty good story (I think) with some visceral impressions of the bar and situation. I don’t recommend anyone drink constantly while writing, but what are you trying to accomplish? If you are writing about the people who may drink too much, you can’t really go there unless you have had a few instances of being drunk, that’s my opinion. I was sitting one time at a dinner with a guy who has had a well-known book in print constantly since the 60’s. I told him, “I used to think I was creative, but I discovered I was just f—-ed up.” He seemed to find this humorous if no less true. I am able to get in touch with the parts of myself that are less than flattering. Yes, I do think I am creative, but getting in touch with my weaknesses is important. Drinking may be one weakness. I have never been addicted to alcohol or drugs, but I do have an addictive personality. Frankly, I think no great character in fiction has ever been written that does not display weakness. So, does alcohol boost my writing creativity? Not at present but it has in the past. Just don’t overdo it or get involved in underage drinking, alcoholism, or drinking and driving please.

I started writing when I was young. I think I was probably 17 when I started actually keeping what I wrote and even shared a few of my poems with my bff at the time. For Christmas one year, I was probably 18 or 19, we didn't have money so we made each other Christmas presents. She made me a journal. The front page a carefully hand designed cover with hole punches and pretty twine to hold the paper to it. I was thrilled! I wrote in that thing daily. I packed it in a box and it sat for a couple of decades before I rediscovered it. How excited I was to find it and read the poems from the younger me who was always in love and always writing about so many things! That's what happens when you smoke too much weed. Your memory goes to shit. So there I was sitting on my couch thumbing through pages and pages and endless pages…. “Got high with (insert name) today.” Pretty much it. Over and over again. Wtf I thought! I wasn't the least bit creative! I was just high and that's it! Very disappointed. So for the 19 year old version of me, marijuana didn't help me be creative at all! I was just stoned. A LOT.

When I composed this answer, none of the other answers mentioned the crucial issues of dose and constituency.  The outcome will be dependent on how much marijuana, which variety, its form and how it's administered. For thinking outside the box, a tiny smoked or vaped dose (say 50 mg of the dried flower, a match head sized portion) of a low myrcene, high-THC cannabis variety that produces a little pinene and limonene makes for an excellent creative stimulus for writing, especially if that variety produces a little CBD (comprising around 10% of its total cannabinoid content.)  A 50 mg dose of this type of cannabis flower when smoked should deliver around 2-4 mg of THC, which is the threshold of psychoactivity.  The class of cannabis variety commonly called Haze, derived from Colombian, Thai and Mexican landrace genetics is ideal, (though contemporary Hazes contain little CBD, so it can be added by taking a tiny dose of oral CBD tincture).  Understanding the basic pharmacology of cannabis enables a user to tune or fashion its effects, especially when dose is carefully monitored.  I find the hyperfocus and increase in associational thinking from low doses of specific varieties of cannabis to be of great assistance when writing.

Its 6 AM in the morning and I am working on my next story. I write short stories and have just started with writing full time. i am compiling a series of short stories encapsulating different professions of different people I have come across, during my lifetime. Recently I interviewed a friend of mine who is an avid trekker and mountaineer. I asked for his experiences and did a bit of research of my own. Everything went south when I started writing. Having had only a few experiences of myself in trekking, it is a difficult task getting into the mind of a professional one, and create nerve-binding narrative and intricate storytelling out of it. Chronicleboat.wordpress.com So I turned to my best friend of years. Weed. The paragraph that I had written at 6 in the morning, considering it my most productive time, turned into 2 full pages and they were with dialogues which I usually despise as a writer. The marijuana actually helps you in concentrating on the topic and the storytelling. It brings beautiful nuances out and helps you pen them down. Every now and then you may deviate from coherent storytelling but that is just reversible collateral damage. Not a junkie, not n addict. Just a functional stoner.

I don't know if it makes you a better writer. But in my case, at least it made a more productive one. I used to work as a reporter for a local newspaper, and my job had three big parts to it: coverage of local events, a column on politics and a coln on local "sociological" issues.  When I first started, I could only do the first since it required almost no creativo effort. I judt had to be at the events, and write down what happened. Getting the two columns was sort of a promotion; now I could finally write freely. Thing is, when I got this, I would spend most of my time thinking about the column, and coverage job started to seem excruciatingly tedious. After a few months, so did my columns. There were times when I just couldn't find any joy in what I was doing, my job became mechanical...it was all just a long agony of dullness and repetitiveness. Marijuana helped me, as it made able to find joy in such dullness. When stoned, everything would become interesting, so I could write about anything. I hardly believe this is the answer you were looking for. Writing, sadly, is not always a magical and creative process. Sometimes it's work, and it's dull. And MJ can help you make it a bit more interesting. As it would do with any other job, I guess.

I agree with Cyril Anderson. When I smoke marijuana I fall in my thoughts and I find them more interesting than normally. They are fresher and newer.  But it is almost impossible, and should not be done if you want to do it properly well, to follow a line and build up a final product.Because you get tripped in thoughts and it is more hard, it is actually struggling, to carry on the same thought. There is no continuity between thoughts, or at least is harder to be, because when a new thought arise I find myself so interested in that new one that I just follow it.  It is not a drug to use when you have to be concentrated on something specific.Marijuana, as hallucinogenic drugs, make you very concentrated but you can't decide the subject. It changes all the time.

I just finished 1 year-long experiment where I microdosed cannabis pretty much daily to boost my creativity as a writer. I discovered that when using cannabis (in right doses) I: can easily get into flowam less critical towards myself, hence more fearless in my writingfeel generally more creative (better plot, better choice of words, more complex sentences, many good comparisons)write faster (around 3 to 4 times the usual speed)find writing much easier, playful, and more funam more passionate about my workcan easily learn from my mistakes and problems (thanks to the insightful nature of the plant)I even wrote a book about it, which I titled “Small Magic” Small Magic: Microdosing cannabis to improve creativity, defeat writer's block, and write faster (a writer's account) Feel free to have a look :) Cannabis is really great. Beside all of the positive effects, it’s cheap, easily available, non-toxic, and from my experience, as good as other psychedelic drugs (like acid).

Trey Parker and Matt Stone have always been accused of smoking weed and writing episodes of South Park. They once said in an interview that, if you know anything about being high, it's that you don't get a lot done. The biggest myth about writing is that "creating an idea" is difficult. After years of practice, the ability to create a great idea is trivial. The other part of the equation, the discipline to sit down and flesh it out, is actually the hard part. I also want to point to Kevin Smith, who does get really high and creates stories. Interesting fact about Smith, though, is that he didn't smoke much pot when he was starting out. He talks about this in some of his podcasts. It wasn't until after he became a disciplined storyteller that he started smoking a lot of pot. So I want to reiterate, once again, that the difficult part of writing is gaining the discipline and patience required to follow the story to its logical conclusion.

Might be helpful for first draft writing or for working up initial notes for articles that you'll finish later. It's not so good for final draft work, because you're not usually as focused. It gives a pleasant flow of new and different ideas, but it's hard to really hammer out one single idea fully, because you'll be in the middle of it, and then some other idea will be prompted that feels just as good, and you need to jump to write it down before you lose it. Marijuana is kind of a bad substance for sticking to one predetermined rigid task. Can be a nice way for a person to brainstorm the start or the initial notes of new pieces. Not so good for finishing at polished production quality.

It helps me lower my creative inhibitions and draw relationships in ways I don’t normally think of. Michael Backes speaks of dose and quality and I believe he’s correct. There isn’t just one strain - there are thousands, all with differing amounts of the chemicals, each with their own effect. Its too simple to assume everyone who smokes weed will have the same experience, but generally those who want creativity can find it in the right quantity and quality of weed.

Let me answer that with an experiment to that effect. The reader may judge for themselves if the story was helped or harmed by what I consumed during the 9 months I spent writing it since it hasn’t been a commercial success, but the few people who have reviewed it give it solid reviews: Amazon.com: The Vimana Incident eBook: Rose LaCroix: Kindle Store Pro tip though: EDIT SOBER. Write your roughs in whatever state you want but when it comes to polishing, make sure you’re clear-headed.

It's been ages since I smoked MJ, but it did work well to conceive of intricate, mind-bending plots. If I were going to use it now, I'd get voice to text software and let it do the typing. I'd also expect to have to do a great deal of continuity editing after sobering up. Writing about pot: Denver Post weed critics smoke and tell

Depends on what strain you are smoking, how your brain reacts to certain cannabinoids, how much you smoke and how long after smoking you are doing your “creative” task. Some strains high in THC will get you so high you might have weird and interesting ideas, but won't be able to put anything together. For me usually smoking cannabis works well before my creative process - that way I can start working when I start coming down from my high into the mellow, chill mindstate I find perfect for working on my creative projects.

Cyril Anderson is right.I think any psychedelic or mind-altering substance can help you think out of the box and get rid of a writers block, but not make you a better artist. Marijuana can be very helpful in weaving intricate plots and schemes in your head, but it's hard to be consistently coherent when stoned.

Seconding the other opinions, MJ is useful in coming up with ideas, be they the genisis of a story or some unexpected fork... Whenever I'm smoking, with the intent or not, I keep a scratch-pad handy for anything that comes to mind.  A lot of it, looked upon with sober eyes, is dreck... but there's some really good stuff too.
